EventStory.Headline: Edited Transcript of KIM earnings conference call or presentation 10-Feb-11 3:00pm GMT
EventStory.Body:
Q4 2010 Kimco Realty Corporation Earnings Conference Call
NEW HYDE PARK Feb 10, 2011 (Thomson StreetEvents) -- Edited Transcript of Kimco Realty Corp earnings conference call or presentation Thursday, February 10, 2011 at 3:00:00pm GMT
TEXT version of Transcript
================================================================================ Corporate Participants ================================================================================ * Milton Cooper KIMCO REALTY CORP - Chairman, CEO * Mike Nelson Kimco Realty Corporation - Unidentified Title, Mexico Team * Barbara Pooley KIMCO REALTY CORP - Senior Vice President, Finance & Investor Relations * Rob Nadler Kimco Realty Corporation - President of Central Region * Glen Cohen KIMCO REALTY CORP - Senior Vice President, Treasurer * Mike Pappagallo KIMCO REALTY CORP - COO * Dave Henry KIMCO REALTY CORP - Chief Investment Officer * David Bujnicki Kimco Realty Corporation - Sr Dir of IR
================================================================================ Conference Call Participants ================================================================================ * Carig Schmidt BofA Merrill Lynch - Analyst * Craig Schmidt BofA Merrill Lynch - Analyst * Paul Morgan Morgan Stanley - Analyst * Quentin Vellely Citigroup - Analyst * Michael Mueller JPMorgan Chase & Co. - Analyst * Alexander (Alex) Goldfarb Sandler O'Neill & Partners - Analyst * Richard Moore RBC Capital Markets - Analyst * Jeffrey Donnelly Wells Fargo Securities - Analyst * Nathan Isbee Stifel Nicolaus - Analyst * Jim Sullivan Cowen and Company - Analyst * Laura Clark Green Street Advisors - Analyst * Jay Habermann Goldman Sachs - Analyst * Vincent Chow Deutsche Bank - Analyst * Samit Parikh ISI Group - Analyst * Ross Nussbaum UBS - Analyst
================================================================================ Presentation -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Operator [1] -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Good morning ladies and gentlemen and welcome to Kimco's fourth quarter earnings conference call. Please be aware today's conference is being recorded. As a reminder all lines are muted to prevent background noise. After the speakers remarks, there'll be a formal question-and-answer session. (Operator Instructions) Due to time constraints please limit yourself to one question. At this time it's my pleasure to introduce your speaker today, Mr. David Bujnicki. Please proceed Sir. -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- David Bujnicki, Kimco Realty Corporation - Sr Dir of IR [2] -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Thank you all for joining the fourth quarter 2010 Kimco earnings call. With me on the call this morning are Milton Cooper, Executive Chairman; Dave Henry, President and Chief Executive Officer; Mike Pappagallo, Chief Operating Officer; Glen Cohen, Chief Financial Officer; as well as other key executives who will be available to address questions at the conclusion of our prepared remarks. As a reminder, statements made during the course of this call represent the Company and Management's hopes, intentions, beliefs, expectations, or projections of the future are forward-looking statements. It is important to note that the Company's actual results could differ materially from those projected in such forward-looking statements. Information concerning factors that could cause actual results to differ materially from those forward-looking statements is contained in this Company's SEC filings. During this presentation, management may make reference to certain non-GAAP financial measures that we believe help investors better understand Kimco's operating results. Examples include, but are not limited to, funds from operations and net operating income. Reconciliation of these non-GAAP financial measures are available on our website. Finally, during the Q&A portion of the call, we request that you respect the limit of one question so that all of our callers have the opportunity to speak with management. Feel free to return to the queue and if you have additional questions, if we have time at the end of the call, we will address them. With that I'll turn the call over to Dave Henry. -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Dave Henry, KIMCO REALTY CORP - Chief Investment Officer [3] -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Our fourth-quarter results reflect another solid quarter of improving fundamentals and a brightening outlook across the retail real estate sector. A third consecutive quarter of positive, same store NOI and good leasing activity, together with continued progress in reducing both our corporate leverage and our non-retail portfolio, leaves us feeling very optimistic about 2011. Retail sales have been strong, and retailer earnings and balance sheets are much improved. With virtually no new speculative retail development, retailers are becoming much more flexible in terms of looking at existing vacancies and effective rents are increasing, albeit still significantly below peak levels. There continues to be substantial geographic differences across our portfolio. Again, highlighting the benefits of diversification and our large-scale platform. Canada, Puerto Rico, and Long Island for example have very few vacancies and rents have held firm during the downturn. Other markets such as Arizona, Southern California, and parts of Florida remains soft. Overall, in an aggregate however, leasing activity and rent levels are improving. With our strong balance sheet, substantial liquidity and multiple large institutional partners, we have selectively begun to acquire high-quality retail properties from third-party owners where the economics are accretive and the locations lie within our targeted markets. We plan to be very disciplined and patient as we evaluate opportunities. But, we will definitely win our share of property acquisitions, given our size, long-standing relationships and our reputation for being a reliable buyer. Beginning in the third quarter of 2010, to date we have purchased and closed on 10 properties from third-party owners. Four for various joint venture partners, and six for our core REIT portfolio. The acquisitions total approximately $269 million and comprise 1.9 million square feet across six states. We continue to be selective and disciplined about purchasing shopping centers of high quality with good, long-term demographics. As noted in our press release, we also continue to make progress in reducing both our portfolio of non-retail investments, and our retail preferred equity holdings. Our non-retail portfolio now stands at roughly $798 million, 130 investments, down from $1 billion, 161 investments at the beginning of 2009. We have good momentum, with our largest investment, InTown Suites, now been formally marketed by an investment banking firm, and a number of other repayments expected to occur in the first quarter. In addition, we have received $15 million in principal payments on the [Volive] convertible bond together with interest payments as scheduled. With respect to our retail preferred equity portfolio, over the past year, we have reduced the amount and number of our retail preferred equity investments from $297 million in 125 properties to $158 million and 92 properties. This has been achieved through a combination of property sales, refinancing, partner exchanges and conversion to (perry) pursuit joint ventures. Good solid progress on this front. As we enter 2011, our priorities remain clear and consistent with prior earnings calls. Our team is focused on; 1, continued improvement in the vital signs and metrics for our shopping centers, occupancy, same store NOI and leasing spreads; 2, achieving stability and lease up in our Latin American portfolio; 3, reducing our non-retail investments and selling our non-strategic retail properties; 4, growing in a disciplined and measured way by acquiring high quality properties in key markets for both our institutional partners and our own portfolio; and 5, further reducing debt and targeting a net debt to EBITDA ratio and 6.0 or lower by 2012. Progress on all these fronts will put us in a strong position to achieve both our income targets and the goals outlined above. We do indeed feel very positive about the improving environment for retail property fundamentals and our retail tenants. Now, I would like to turn it over to Glen for a detailed review of our quarterly financial results. And later, Mike Pappagallo will talk in depth about our property operations in various portfolio initiatives. And then, Milton will close with his perspective on the current environment for property acquisitions and values. -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Glen Cohen, KIMCO REALTY CORP - Senior Vice President, Treasurer [4] -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Thanks Dave, and good morning.Our activity during the fourth quarter exhibits further evidence and progress on all aspects of our strategy, and priorities that Dave just described. As we reported last night, we finished the year with headline fourth quarter FFO per share of $0.29 bringing the full year FFO per share results to $1.13, beating consensus estimates of $0.28 and $1.12 for the quarter and full year respectively. As many of the other pertinent numbers are disclosed in the press release and supplemental package, I will not spend significant time on those this morning. However, we continue to focus on recurring FFO which excludes non-recurring income and impairments. So, I will provide more insights here. For the fourth quarter, recurring FFO was $119.7 million, or $0.29 per diluted share, and for the full year it was $465.4 million, or $1.14 per share. A 5% increase over the 2009 amount of $444 million. Full year 2009 recurring FFO per diluted share was $1.26. The recurring FFO dollar increase is attributable to a 6.8% increase in recurring retail FFO, offset by lower recurring non-retail FFO and increased financing costs including the preferred dividends. Our shopping center portfolio continues to show resilience an improvement. We ended the year with occupancy of 92.7% including our pro rata share for the total combined portfolio. Occupancy for the US portfolio was 92.4%, flat to last year but up 50 basis points to 92.7%, without regard to percentage ownership. Our same site NOI increased by 1.8%. This represents our third consecutive quarter with positive same site results. Mike will take a deeper look at the shopping center operating performance in a moment. During 2010, we made significant progress toward our strategic initiative of reducing our non-retail portfolio. We sold seven urban assets, monetized $42 million of mortgages and equity and debt securities, disposed of four preferred equity investments, received a distribution from our Albertsons investment, and a partial repayment on the Vilad convertible bond. All totaled, we received cash proceeds of approximately $130 million, reduced the book basis by $110 million, offset by a $30 million increase primarily related to currency improvements on our foreign investments while recognizing gains in excess of $20 million. In addition, during January, an additional repayment of $7 million was made by Vilad. Keep in mind the non-retail investments represent only 7% of gross total assets, and about 6% of EBITDA contribution. We remain focused on the disposition of these assets. During the quarter, we sold 5 non-strategic retail assets from the consolidated portfolio, and 3 others from the joint venture programs for approximately $35 million. We remain committed to our recycling program and expect to raise $150 million or more from property sales during 2011. As discussed in our Investor Day, we plan to use the proceeds from the sale of non-strategic retail assets to pursue acquisitions primarily in our target markets. Since then, we have acquired 3 wholly owned unencumbered properties and 2 out parcels for $56 million. In addition, we invested $43 million to acquire interest in 3 joint venture properties. Now, we did have our share of non-cash impairments this quarter, totaling $24 million. These charges are primarily related to assets either sold or under contract and include a mixed use joint venture development project and a hotel asset we expect to sell in the first quarter. As for the balance sheet, we concluded the year with net debt to recurring EBITDA of 6.3 times, ahead of our target of 6.5 times for 2010, and an absolute reduction in debt of $375 million. As a result of the non-recurring income in the fourth quarter, the headline net debt to EBITDA was 5.3 times. However, we view the recurring EBITDA as the more meaningful measure, and will continue to report on a recurring basis. By way of reference, we began the year at 7.4 times on a recurring EBITDA basis. We are committed to achieving our goal of net debt to recurring EBITDA of 6 times by the end of 2012, and further improving our fixed charge coverage. Our liquidity position remains in excellent shape with over $1.6 billion of immediate liquidity and only $110 million of consolidated debt maturities for all of 2011. Now, although we have no immediate capital raising needs, it is encouraging to see our unsecured debt spreads continue to compress. They are now in the mid 100's. And willingness of the commercial banks to lend has significantly increased. If this trend continues, it may be a catalyst for new business startups which would help build a small shop space. All in all, 2010 was a very productive year for us. We achieved total shareholder return of 39%, exceeding the [Navy] Equity REIT Index, which came in at 28%, and the Retail Sector Index at just over 33%. Now for a look at what we expect for 2011. First, we have completed our detailed property by property budget process, and as a result, reaffirm our 2011 FFO per share guidance range of $1.17 to $1.21. This guidance range is based on recurring flows and does not include non-recurring transaction income or charges for impairments, if any. Assumption in determining the guidance range include; occupancy improvement of 50 basis points to 75 basis points, same property NOI flat to a positive 2%, investment of $250 million in property acquisitions funded with $150 million from shopping center dispositions for net investment of $100 million, and an additional $7 million to $8 million of FFO contribution from the Mexico portfolio. Based on these assumptions, our current annualized dividend of $0.72 provides a conservative FFO payout ratio of about 60%. And now, I will turn it over to Mike for his report on the shopping center portfolio. -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Mike Pappagallo, KIMCO REALTY CORP - COO [5] -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Thanks Glen, Good morning everyone.We had a very productive quarteras the vital signs of the business continue to march forward well past the low points of the recession into a steadily improving environment. First, in terms of occupancy. The headline US occupancy of 92.4% increase by 10 basis points from the prior quarter, and was flat year-over-year. Now, this is pro rata occupancy, and the impact of positive net absorption for the full year was offset by the inclusion of 7 former development projects with lower occupancy, and our ownership changes from property transfers to new joint ventures. But the underlying portfolio activity and progress is much better than at first blush. Looking at the US portfolio metrics, without regard to ownership percentages, overall leased occupancy was up by 50 basis points from the beginning of the year on the strength of positive net absorption of 700,000 square foot of space. Throughout this past year, we've been often discussed the increasing appetite for space by national and regional retail chains, reflecting their strong financial results, the recovery and decreasing supply due to the curtailment of development. Our portfolio benefited from this trend as we signed, on a gross square footage basis, over 4 million square feet of new leases during the year. Of which about a little over half was for spaces over 10,000 square feet. We continue to be encouraged by the opportunities for absorption of these mid box and larger box spaces as we enter 2011. That said, we need to keep our eye on specific situations, such as the A&P bankruptcy, and the current issues confronting borders. On the other side of the coin, we've also expressed caution on the prospects for small store leasing due to the limited availability of credit and uneven recovery in certain markets. On that score, we are seeing gradual improvement and stabilization. New leases versus vacates were roughly a push over the past two quarters for small store leasing. Our view is that the worst is over. So, we see 2011 with upside opportunity from the perspective of leasing velocity on small tenants. To put that in perspective, our quarterly financial supplement now discloses the occupancy per space 10,000 square foot or greater, and that less than 10,000 per square feet. The occupancy for the larger space is over 95%. The small store level is 82%. Another sign of stabilizing markets, our rental spread (on renewals) and options, exercised from existing tenants. While only slightly positive, keeping tenants in place is the more important factor as it underscores the viability of the center and avoids downtime and increased cost to find new users. As I've mentioned on previous calls, new leasing spreads for a given quarter can be influenced by selective leases, and this quarter was no exception. As 3 of the 67 leases in the same store population accounted for half of the 14% decline for the quarter using the 12 month downtime. Interestingly, one significant lease roll down was for a space that was dark and paying when we bought the property in 2007. We knew the rent was above market and lowered the purchase price accordingly. The second lease was a deal we elected to sign as-is for 5 years as we expect to position that property for redevelopment down the road. And the third, was a deal that involved, and solved, a co-tenancy that net/net generates more NOI from the property overall. My point here is that new leasing spreads in any single quarter does not necessarily tell the whole story. We focus on the historical trend of rental rate, and yes, as a trend, market rents have fallen significantly over the past two years. What we're seeing now, though, over the past two quarters is that the rental rates are stabilizing. In 2011, I think we will continue to see headlined new leasing spreads still in negative territory as many of the leases are roll-offs from the heady days prior to the recession. But, as we recapture large spaces with below market rents in 2012, and 2013 and beyond, we expect to return to healthy, positive new leasing spreads in the aggregate. Same site net operating income, as you heard, came in at 1.8%. Our same-store numbers started trending up back in the fourth quarter of last year and I think the 2010 results underscore the resiliency and diversity of our portfolio. By now, most of you are aware of our longer-term strategy to recycle out of what we are calling our non-strategic shopping center assets. And we are getting on with it. Even prior to Investor Day, we had begun the process as we sold 4 properties that fit the profile earlier in the year. Since September's Investor Day through today, we have disposed of 10 more properties and have an additional 10 either under contract or negotiating contracts. We expect to have 30 or so properties in the market by the first half of 2011. Many are already out there. And while operating with a sense of urgency, we will be prudent in our decision-making, and if we feel there is additional lease up opportunity to improve the prospects in pricing of this position, we will take a longer-term view. But the endgame is clear, to recycle. And the cash that we generate from the sale, coupled with available capital from our institutional sources, has opened up the gate for us to consider selected acquisition opportunities, as Dave mentioned. In the last half of 2010, we bought properties for our own account, as well as acquiring a property with an existing institutional partner, SEB, and a second property jointly with RioCan and a local operator. Each of these deals reinforce our strategy to pursue assets in targeted markets where we have scale, or other markets where we can find well priced assets. Our purchase of a giant anchor center added to our already strong position in the mid-Atlantic corridor. The purchase of centers in El Paso and Jacksonville represented opportunistic buys of assets with tenants such as Lowe's, Kohl's, and TJ Maxx. The property acquired in the Raleigh area was a negotiated deal, and is adjacent to an existing Kimco center. We've closed two additional properties in 2011 and will continue a disciplined pursuit of those deals. Outside of the US, Mexico remains -- lease up remains a top priority. Leasing conditions continued to improve in Mexico. In 2010 we signed new deals aggregating over 700,000 square feet versus 570,000 square feet in 2009. Our operating plan calls for an additional 700,000 plus square foot of leasing activity in 2011. I'll put context around this number. The composite occupancy of the portfolio of 55 Mexico shopping centers, including projects still a development and those built within lease up, is currently about 79%. We look to increase that to about 84% by year-end 2011. In Canada, the operating portfolio continues to meet all of our high expectations. As Dave mentioned, we have been converting some of our preferred equity investments into straight up co-ownership positions, including our portfolio of gross or anchored centers in the Vancouver area and a 700,000 square foot power center outside of Montreal that we announced last quarter. This asset not only has a terrific lineup of tenants in the first phase of the project, but our position to start up the next phase of project due to the strong interest from both US and Canadian retailers. In sum, I'd say that we are looking for 2011 to be a moderately improving, but not spectacular operating climate. However, we expect to make more substantive improvements in Kimco's asset valuation through continued positive absorption, meaningful recycling, reinvestment in our core assets and selective acquisitions. And now to Mr. Cooper. -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Milton Cooper, KIMCO REALTY CORP - Chairman, CEO [6] -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Firstly, I would like to congratulate our CEO, Dave Henry. At the winter meeting of the trustees and the International Council of Shopping Centers, Dave was nominated to be the next Chairman of the ICSC. Trustees gave Dave a standing ovation and is just further evidence of the respect that Dave has among his peers. Now, Dave, Mike, and Glenn have described the excellent result of our quarter, and our progress in actions moving toward achieving the strategic goals we have outlined. We have a good business model. We have a portfolio that has a steady increase in cash flow, and a management team that can find ways to profit from the perturbations in the retail real estate market. My own view is that cash flows from long-term leases in our portfolio are substantially undervalued. In my opinion, we are in an environment where hard assets are in great demand and growing cash flows in shopping centers will have cap rates that will be below 6%. I mention this against the background of the issues of so many states and municipalities. Who would've thought that the credit to the great states of California, Illinois, and Michigan would become suspect? Who would've thought that the prices of their municipal bonds would plummet? Who would've thought that certain cities in California would be able to settle obligations at substantial discounts?As a consequence, cash flows of shopping centers located on major thoroughfares and strong markets are a wonderful safe haven. Demand for retail space is increasing because there are very few new developments, and many retailers are experiencing angst as they weather, wonder whether they will be able to meet their expansion plans for 2012 store openings. Over time, we will have inflation and we will have growth in cash flow and growth in value. Now, this November, we will celebrate the 20th anniversary of our initial public offering. Despite the vicissitudes of the market, our investors have earned a total return of 1103%, and an average annual return of 13.8% since the initial IPO. I am proud of the record, and we are ready for the next phase of our growth. I thank our terrific team, and we now welcome your questions. -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- David Bujnicki, Kimco Realty Corporation - Sr Dir of IR [7] -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Operator we're ready to move on to the question-and-answer portion of the call. Please respect the limit of one question. ================================================================================ Questions and Answers -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Operator [1] -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- (Operator Instructions) Craig Schmidt with Bank of America. -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Carig Schmidt, BofA Merrill Lynch - Analyst [2] -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- I was wondering if you could describe the leasing environment in Mexico right now, and do that from both a US-based retailer standpoint and a Mexican-based retailer standpoint? -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Dave Henry, KIMCO REALTY CORP - Chief Investment Officer [3] -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Sure. And, we've asked Mike Nelson, who runs our Mexico team, to be on the call today. And, I think I would like to might give his perspective and then I will come across on the top. Mike? If you there? -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Mike Nelson, Kimco Realty Corporation - Unidentified Title, Mexico Team [4] -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Sure. I am. You know, I think in general, as Mike mentioned, we are seeing improvements overall in the environment. You know, the US retailers, especially the anchors such as Wal-Mart, HEB, Home Depot, and others are back expanding again. Wal-Mart aggressively so, opened almost 300 stores last year and expects to do a similar amount this year. On the Mexico side, I think we've been pleasantly surprised by the re-emergence of national sub-anchor tenants, who had essentially halted their expansion for the last 18 months. Over the past six months, we have seen them aggressively come back and seek new store count, and in many of our properties we've got multiple bids on some of our sub-anchor spaces. So, I think overall we are seeing an improvement in the environment, especially from the Mexican retailers. -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Dave Henry, KIMCO REALTY CORP - Chief Investment Officer [5] -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Craig, I just would add a couple comments on the US side. From retailers, it really divides into two camps. The US retailers that are already there in Mexico and have profited and are doing well have resumed their expansion or never stop their expansion plans, like the Home Depot and Wal-Mart in others. Other retailers that had been looking at Mexico as an expansion opportunity, I think it's fair to say they've given pause to that and are taking a hard look and would like to see further evidence that the violence levels have decreased and the government is winning that battle. So, I think it is fair to say US retailers that aren't already there are a little bit apprehensive about going to Mexico. But the ones that are there, have ramped it up again. -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Craig Schmidt, BofA Merrill Lynch - Analyst [6] -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Do you think the leasing spreads will be positive this year? -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Barbara Pooley, KIMCO REALTY CORP - Senior Vice President, Finance & Investor Relations [7] -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- In Mexico you mean? -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Craig Schmidt, BofA Merrill Lynch - Analyst [8] -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Yes, I'm sorry, still just Mexico. Sorry. -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Barbara Pooley, KIMCO REALTY CORP - Senior Vice President, Finance & Investor Relations [9] -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- It's hard, it's hard to look at the leasing spreads in Mexico because there are so, there are so few leases that are really showing up in the leasing spreads. It's only on the base it's been released down there. And I realize that it looks a bit odd when you look at the supplemental and see negative leasing spreads in Mexico, but keep in mind, those are on very, very small spaces in -- and a very small number of leases that comprise that. So it can be a bit of a skewed data point. -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Dave Henry, KIMCO REALTY CORP - Chief Investment Officer [10] -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- As I've mentioned before, Craig, Mexico is unusual in that the local stores are maybe only 350 square feet, 400 square feet, so the size of a motel room compared to US local stores that are 2000 square feet. -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Craig Schmidt, BofA Merrill Lynch - Analyst [11] -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Okay. Thank you. -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Operator [12] -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Paul Morgan with Morgan Stanley. -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Paul Morgan, Morgan Stanley - Analyst [13] -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- I appreciate the breakout for the vacancy with the shops and the anchors. Could you just talk about where, where it was the peak occupancy for the shops? And kind of what the, where the catalysts are to sort of get back to that? I mean does it mimic the -- I assume it's nowhere near kind of where you were overall, but kind of what is a stabilized number? And kind of how -- what do you think a reasonable expectation is, to get back to that? -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- David Bujnicki, Kimco Realty Corporation - Sr Dir of IR [14] -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Paul, what we can tell you is that when you think about the peak occupancy overall, it was in the 96% level, and you, as you know, we did not break it down into these two components. But I think it's safe to say that at the height of the market, that the larger spaces are probably a couple points or two even more occupied than they were in the stat I gave you. And then doing the math, obviously the small stores spaces were probably over 90%. Yes, they were over 90%. So, I think that's the best I can offer you considering we didn't have -- we didn't focus on those breakdowns historically. -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Dave Henry, KIMCO REALTY CORP - Chief Investment Officer [15] -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- But it is somewhat encouraging, from where we sit, that even the local stores are showing some, some progress again. Especially national retailers with small store footprints. Those guys are expanding again. The local mom and pops are continuing to struggle, especially in certain geographic areas, credit's still constrained for a single store operator. But, across the board, even the small shops we're feeling better about. -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Paul Morgan, Morgan Stanley - Analyst [16] -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Great. Thanks. -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Operator [17] -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Quentin Velleley with Citi. -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Quentin Vellely, Citigroup - Analyst [18] -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Just wanted to focus on the non-core assets, and I guess my question has two parts. Firstly, with the [Vilad] notes, can you give us an update on the strategic review they're undergoing? And also the management buyout proposal and what that could mean for the repayment of your notes? And then secondly, just with the InTown suites that you are marketing, just wondering if you can give us an EBITDA number for 2010 and possibly 2011 so we can get a handle on the potential valuation? -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Dave Henry, KIMCO REALTY CORP - Chief Investment Officer [19] -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Well, I think you managed to sneak in (inaudible) question there. (laughter) But we will take them one at a time. And in fairness to the lot, I think you have to look at their public press releases to really get more color. But it's fair to say that the Board is looking at various strategic alternatives including an outright sale of the Company, a merger of the Company, selling off major asset groups, and interestingly enough, their former CEO is leading a management buyout proposal of their European management business, which the board is now wrestling with. Obviously there is a built-in conflict there with the former CEO stepping aside and then leading an offer to buy the European business. So, it's fair to say there is lots of moving parts and they, they are looking at significant asset sales as they try to reduce their, their debt levels over time. They recently announced that a major hotel property that they recently got the full title to is now on the market. So, as these sales occur, we are hopeful that they will be able to make further principal reductions. We're pleased that we received $15 million so far, and they remaining fully current on, on the interest payment, which is a nice 9.5%. So, we wish them well, and we will see how it goes. With respect to InTown, we are pleased that we finally herded all the cats together and it's now formally in the market with an investment banking group. We have 138 properties, as you probably know, we feel very good about the month-to-month increases in what they call Rev Par, clearly the operations are, are doing better. I don't want to give you a prediction for this year, but you can, it's fair to assume it's going to do significantly better in terms of bottom-line results than, than last year. And, we feel good about the timing in terms of hitting the market with, with these properties. Our basis is substantially below replacement value and the extended stay segment is doing very well. So, so we remain hopeful that we will make progress and get good, good activity on, on buying this, this platform. Because as you know we own the hotels and we own the platform itself. -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Quentin Vellely, Citigroup - Analyst [20] -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Did you have an EBITDA number for 2010? For InTown? -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Mike Pappagallo, KIMCO REALTY CORP - COO [21] -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- You know, as you know, that obviously is a private company. But what I can tell you, though, is if you look at the net operating income disclosures in our supplement, in the Other Investment section, there is a number which is about $51 million. Most of that is attributable to the InTown investment as it is the largest piece of the Other Investment puzzle, and we expect that, I'd say, (inaudible). -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Glen Cohen, KIMCO REALTY CORP - Senior Vice President, Treasurer [22] -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Is probably around 15% to 20% higher than it was from last year. So the Rev Par is really starting to ramp up. -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Dave Henry, KIMCO REALTY CORP - Chief Investment Officer [23] -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- And we have to respect the fact that we do have other partners in this transaction, so we can't give you 100% of the full details. But, we are feeling very good about it. -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Glen Cohen, KIMCO REALTY CORP - Senior Vice President, Treasurer [24] -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- It's clearly heading in the right direction. -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Dave Henry, KIMCO REALTY CORP - Chief Investment Officer [25] -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Right direction. -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Quentin Vellely, Citigroup - Analyst [26] -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- That's great. I appreciate it. Thank you. -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Operator [27] -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Michael Mueller with JPMorgan. -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Michael Mueller, JPMorgan Chase & Co. - Analyst [28] -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Actually it was just answered. Thanks. -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Dave Henry, KIMCO REALTY CORP - Chief Investment Officer [29] -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Okay. -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Mike Pappagallo, KIMCO REALTY CORP - COO [30] -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- That the negative question. (laughter) -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Operator [31] -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Alex Goldfarb with Sandler O'Neill. -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Alexander (Alex) Goldfarb, Sandler O'Neill & Partners - Analyst [32] -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- I'll try a Quentin Velleley two-parter. (laughter)Just -- on the NOI growth, just focusing on this, the mom and pops that you spoke about, that sounds like they are slowly getting some credit help but it still tough going. The two-part is; one, are you still seeing a prevalence of franchise, or financing; and then two, on your flat to 2% guidance, if, if credit were flowing once again to the mom and pops, what do you think the mom and pops would add to your same store growth? -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Mike Pappagallo, KIMCO REALTY CORP - COO [33] -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- I will answer the second question first. In that the 0% to 2% range is just that. It represents a beneficial, or good case on the high end, meaning some recovery and some occupancy increase and positive absorption on the small store space, as we -- as Glen talked about on his guidance projections. So, I think the guidance, the same-store guidance represents a moderate improvement in small store leasing and improvement in absorption. If there was a significant increase in credit availability, and the economy really took off in that, on that score, we could probably exceed that. But, like many things, our guidance is balanced. For the first part of the question, maybe just a turn to the general perspective of small store credit availability and the impact. We have Rob Nadler on the phone. Rob, if, perhaps you could give a few words, perspectives on small ticket leasing. -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Rob Nadler, Kimco Realty Corporation - President of Central Region [34] -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- With regard to franchise or financing, I mean you're seeing quite a bit of activity in fitness clubs, fitness 19's of the world, health oriented, some non-retail oriented, a little bit of slowdown in fast food and restaurants per se, but it hasn't been a huge influx, you know to the small shop leasing program to date. But, in general, the earnings, especially for the national and the, and the regional retailers they are coming off such strong earnings and such strong cash balances in 2010, with projections for continued modest increases in earnings, that, that there is a good optimism out there in the leasing environment in general. -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Alexander (Alex) Goldfarb, Sandler O'Neill & Partners - Analyst [35] -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Okay. Thank you. -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Operator [36] -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Rich Moore with RBC Capital Markets. -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Richard Moore, RBC Capital Markets - Analyst [37] -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- You know, with tenant demand growing as you guys pointed out, and supply of good space kind of tightening, what are your thoughts on potential, new development starts going forward? -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Dave Henry, KIMCO REALTY CORP - Chief Investment Officer [38] -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Well, this is a favorite topic of mine, and it's debated across the industry. I, I firmly feel that the large scale speculative development, where developers or even, even REITs like ours go out and buy land, get it in title, zone, get an anchor tenant, and take the risk of leasing the rest of the center, we're several years away from that. What you will see is where we and others own land already and it's sitting there and we can get some demand and make it income-producing, you may see some of that, you'll see some redevelopment, you'll see some expansions. But in terms of getting back to millions of square feet being developed across the board, and adding to the inventory of retail space, I personally just don't see it and most in the industry don't see it. If you think about it, credit is not available, construction financing is not available for this, large scale equity bets are not available for this. Tenant rents aren't high enough to justify it. I just think it's going to be very limited for quite a while. -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Richard Moore, RBC Capital Markets - Analyst [39] -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Great. That covers it. Thanks, Dave. -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Operator [40] -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Jeff Donnelly with Wells Fargo. -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Jeffrey Donnelly, Wells Fargo Securities - Analyst [41] -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- If I could just circle back to the small shop leasing. I'm curious whether or not small shop deals are consummated, where would you put the volume of inquiries today versus say the peak of activity, which I would guess to be between 2005 and 2007? -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Mike Pappagallo, KIMCO REALTY CORP - COO [42] -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Rob, you probably could cover that one as well. -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Rob Nadler, Kimco Realty Corporation - President of Central Region [43] -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- I don't know. It would be, you know, an educated guess in terms of you know percentage of inquiries. As was stated by several of us on the phone, credit, credit continues to be tight for the local mom and pop to either expand or invest in their business. So, it's still down substantially in terms of the inquiries, you know, from the local mom-and-pop. They are the last ones to feel the recovery. Unlike the large, national chains who were able to reduce their expense side of the equation because of their massive scale and their ability to source better and cut inventory and cut overhead, the local operator did not have that advantage throughout the recession. So, they are, they are in tougher, tougher straights today. But, consumer confidence is increasing. If we can get some employment growth going, the guys that have hung on through this recession, as Mike said, it sort of bottomed out, the guys that have hung on are guys that are good merchants, that are executing, and had the wherewithal to withstand recession. So, I suspect that we will see some modest but steady growth in the inquiry and in the activity. -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Mike Pappagallo, KIMCO REALTY CORP - COO [44] -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- So, and Jeff what I would add to that is that depending on the market, I mean, if we are talking about small store activity and number of inquiries, talking about (inaudible) days market, Long Island, some of our mid-Atlantic states, it's been very firm. But you know, in California and Arizona, some of the areas that were hardest hit, it's an uneven traction. And again, I think that's where, longer-term, the possibilities had can benefit is if there is some pickup in small store leasing. As I mentioned earlier, it is very regional in its focus. -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Jeffrey Donnelly, Wells Fargo Securities - Analyst [45] -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- So come when you look at small shop tenants of, I guess I'll call it national or regional nature, were maybe credit is less of a concern for them, are you seeing more or less interest from those retailers expanding? Or are they just skittish because of lack of sales production? Or is it just rent and deal terms that are holding them back? -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Mike Pappagallo, KIMCO REALTY CORP - COO [46] -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- No, there's more, there is an increase they are fairly aggressively today. I mean if you take the Famous Footwear's, or the Shoe Carnival's, of the world or the Dress Barn's of the world with their [Moresus] division, and Justice, which is doing where well, they are hungry. They are hungry for space, and as Milton indicated, they are concerned about the lack of development not providing the opportunities for them to me there growth objectives. So, no, they are strong today and looking to grow and being more adaptive and flexible than ever because of the lack of new construction and development. -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Jeffrey Donnelly, Wells Fargo Securities - Analyst [47] -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- So they are taking share, in other words? -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Mike Pappagallo, KIMCO REALTY CORP - COO [48] -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- They're what? -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Jeffrey Donnelly, Wells Fargo Securities - Analyst [49] -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- They're taking share, so to speak? -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Mike Pappagallo, KIMCO REALTY CORP - COO [50] -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Yes. They are out there. There out there and they are doing deals. -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Jeffrey Donnelly, Wells Fargo Securities - Analyst [51] -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Thank you. -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Operator [52] -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Nathan Isbee with Stifel Nicolaus. -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Nathan Isbee, Stifel Nicolaus - Analyst [53] -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Just going back to the same-store NOI guidance. I understand there is some caution built in there, but if I just take the NOI coming online from leases you already signed, your contractual rent bumps, the fact that your renewals have been basically flat to slightly positive, could you just help me understand the bottom end of that guidance a little better? Is it fair to say that something would have to change dramatically to get there? -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Glen Cohen, KIMCO REALTY CORP - Senior Vice President, Treasurer [54] -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Yes. I would offer that both the bankruptcies that have been announced as well as some speculation on other enterprises that may go bankrupt, could, in the short term, put a crimp in terms of, in terms of net operating income at least for the short-term. You think about down time, et cetera. So that was really the primary driver on the low-end. As we spoke about earlier, longer term, many of those spaces for those tenants like Blockbuster, our A&P exposures, our discussion at Investor Day about Borders, in terms of recycling the rent and the market rent of spaces we feel pretty comfortable that there's no, that there isn't long-term damage in terms of our cash flows. But, you're always going to have some shorter term down, downtime in re-leasing vacant space. -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Nathan Isbee, Stifel Nicolaus - Analyst [55] -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- All right. Thanks. -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Operator [56] -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Jim Sullivan with Cowan Group. -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Jim Sullivan, Cowen and Company - Analyst [57] -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- I have really a geographic question . For some time, California and Florida have been your two largest markets and you alluded to, I guess, the fact that Florida you have some recovery in some markets, not in others. What I would love to hear is some granularity regarding the individual markets in both Florida and California in terms of where you are comfortable with the outlook, where you're, where you think it's going to take longer for recovered to take hold? And how that impacts your decisions and thought process on dispositions and -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Mike Pappagallo, KIMCO REALTY CORP - COO [58] -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- In taking Florida, (inaudible) the things we've said very often that our portfolio and southern Florida, Miami, Dade area, Fort Lauderdale, Broward County, et cetera, has been and continues to be very strong in terms of occupancy, tenancy, et cetera. So, we've done very well through there. Our issues have been mostly on the West Coast of Florida. When you think about everything up from central Florida and Orlando, Tampa, St. Pete, et cetera. That's been a difficult market, we continue to see pressure on leasing spreads, there has been some improvement, but there's still a ways to go. And we are focused, obviously, on our small ticket leasing in that area. California, obviously a large state. We have a significant exposure there. I would say that northern California, for us, the Bay Area remains very strong and has continued to do so. We've got a lot of signature properties up there. In southern California, many of which were acquired from the Pan Pacific acquisition, there again we've really been disproportionately hurt in terms of small ticket, small ticket leasing or small store space. The rents were quite high from earlier, that were signed five years, ten years ago. So there's been a lot of pressure in that arena as well. That said, Jim, when I made my earlier comment about new leases and vacates being a push in total, I think one of the things we are encouraged by is that in recent quarters in the southern California portfolio, that we have been signing almost as many leases as we've been, as tenants have been vacating. So we are starting to see a bit of a turn in terms of the velocity in small ticket leasing in southern California. -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Operator [59] -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Laura Clark with Green Street Advisors. -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Laura Clark, Green Street Advisors - Analyst [60] -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- As you look at your availability of capital and narrowing spreads versus the tight credit market that the local operators are experiencing today, how you think about essentially being a bank for those tenants? And how does that impact the amount of TIs you're willing to provide? And lastly, how do you price the risk associated with the additional investment? -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Glen Cohen, KIMCO REALTY CORP - Senior Vice President, Treasurer [61] -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Well I don't think we are going to be a bank to the tenants. I mean we have certainly over the last two years added more TI allowance where it's been needed to fill the spaces. I actually think also for the tenants, you are going to see over the next six months to 18 months that they are going to start to be able to access more capital from the commercial banks. It always starts with a large, better credits. We've seen our credit spreads come in dramatically. Again, our [10 year] spreads today are in the mid 100s, and you're starting to see loosening up somewhat from the commercial bank level. So, I think you're going to see improvement come over that time period. But, we are not really changing our stripes in terms of being the banks of the tenants. -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Laura Clark, Green Street Advisors - Analyst [62] -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Okay. Great. Thank you. -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Operator [63] -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Jay Habermann with Goldman Sachs. -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Jay Habermann, Goldman Sachs - Analyst [64] -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Dave, a question on sort of investor interest at this point in the non-strategic retail, and what sort of returns are these opportunistic investors looking for? -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Dave Henry, KIMCO REALTY CORP - Chief Investment Officer [65] -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Well, it depends on why we put it in the non-strategic bucket, if you will. In terms of the shopping centers, we've got some very good shopping centers, they just don't happen to be in our core market and those trade at very low cap rates. We've got some other shopping centers that are B properties, or have issues, that are going to trade eight, 8 to 9-ish cap rates at the end of the day. So it really depends on where, where that property is. Interestingly, if you take it one more step and look at our non-core, non-retail, the level of interest -- we get calls every day now; We heard you guys are selling some non-retail stuff. The amount of cash that is sitting out there wanting to invest in, in decent, decent real estate is just quite amazing to me. And, people are tired of getting virtually no return. So anything that's cash flowing is of interest today. -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Jay Habermann, Goldman Sachs - Analyst [66] -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- And question for Mike on the above market rents and some of the markets that are still challenged, what is the timeframe for that to burn off, I guess? I mean are you looking at this as sort of the next two years? -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Mike Pappagallo, KIMCO REALTY CORP - COO [67] -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- I would say that's fair, Jay. I alluded to, in my prepared remarks, about 2012 and 2013 where positive spreads would be driven very much by almost any of the below-market rates anchor leases that are coming due, some of which we put forth in our Investor Day material. As it relates to the small store, small ticket leasing, you are seeing destabilization occur, and really the critical difference is spreads are against a contract rate versus discussion about market rates, then and now. We see market rates stabilizing across the board. It's just a question of what was the old contract rate, and there needs to be a little bit more [betting] out of some of those older leases, at older contract rents before we get into positive absorption. -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Jay Habermann, Goldman Sachs - Analyst [68] -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Okay. Thank you. -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Operator [69] -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Vincent Chow with Deutsche Bank. -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Vincent Chow, Deutsche Bank - Analyst [70] -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Just have a longer-term question, just with A&P and (inaudible) value after their quarters. In terms of your, the second tier and third tier sort of grocers, what is your longer-term view of this group in relation to the Wal-Marts and Targets and Costco's of the world? -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Dave Henry, KIMCO REALTY CORP - Chief Investment Officer [71] -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Also take a pass at that. Clearly, with groceries, with grocers of the traditional grocers, so much of it is dependent these days about their location in terms of where they are at as well as their own operating strategies. We can talk about grocers who do very well either in their specific market, like an HEB, or a Wegman's, or some of the larger operators like Publix and Harris Teeter and others who do very well for their markets. So a lot depends on operating strategy, the execution, the ability to deliver the product, and to maintain good quality product in good markets. That said, it is apparent that there is so much competitive pressure coming in from the Super Wal-Marts, the SuperTargets, even the drugstores providing some level of food, the warehouse clubs. It's on and on and on. So from our perspective, as we look at our own exposure as we look at buying properties, selling properties, redeveloping properties, we are now getting into a [pinary] decision in terms of all grocery anchor centers are good, all big box centers are bad. You're basically looking at the strength of the retailer, where they are in the competitive environment, the viability of the space that continue to be, primarily a super market if that particular tenant or retailer failed, and so on. So it is a complicated equation, and admittedly, Vince, I think there's been a little bit too much simplistic thinking about grocery versus big box in the current environment for valuation purposes. But clearly, we talk to our grocery tenants, they are feeling increasing pressure these days by the number of other outlets for food, even dollar stores and convenience stores and so forth. So they anticipate there is going to be margin pressure. You combine that with commodity prices going up, their inventory going up, and some of the things that have held firm during the recession, prepared foods, and store labels that have served them well, that's going to be less of a factor for them. So, I read a lot of these guys as a little bit worried now, and, about where, where it's going. And as Mike pointed out, when we, when we buy new grocery anchored centers we are taking a very hard look at the rent, and whether we can replace that with another user, if possible. -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Vincent Chow, Deutsche Bank - Analyst [72] -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Okay. And are there any particular grocers that you have concerns of currently? Outside of the ones that are -- ? -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Dave Henry, KIMCO REALTY CORP - Chief Investment Officer [73] -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- We love all our tenants. (laughter) -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- David Bujnicki, Kimco Realty Corporation - Sr Dir of IR [74] -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- We particularly love the grocers that are privately owned, like HE Butt, Publix, Wegman's, (inaudible). -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Dave Henry, KIMCO REALTY CORP - Chief Investment Officer [75] -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- We don't say bad things about anybody on a conference. (laughter) -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Vincent Chow, Deutsche Bank - Analyst [76] -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Got you. -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Dave Henry, KIMCO REALTY CORP - Chief Investment Officer [77] -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Anybody that pays us rent is a wonderful tenant. -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Vincent Chow, Deutsche Bank - Analyst [78] -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Got it. Thanks. -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Operator [79] -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- (Operator Instructions) Samit Parikh with ISI Group -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Samit Parikh, ISI Group - Analyst [80] -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- My question really has to do with sort of valuations in the market right now. I've asked this of other companies, and I'm curious what you guys have to say as well in terms of what sort of underwritten, unlevered, tenured IRRs are you guys targeting? And your core acquisition that you're looking at right now? And how does that differ in terms of from, you know, the [in-fill] stuff that you're looking at investing versus more of the middle-market things? What's really the spread there? -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Dave Henry, KIMCO REALTY CORP - Chief Investment Officer [81] -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Well, as you know, IRRs are very dependent on exit cap rates and, and your assumptions. I think we start by looking at the unlevered cap rate that we are going in at and whether that's sustainable. Most good quality properties, I think we can bank on somewhere around 2% annual growth, and if we can get that, and if we can buy it at 7.5% to an 8% unlevered return, I, we think that's pretty accretive and we would consider that for, for our core. As to higher quality properties get down closer to 6% cap, we do look at those as a product for our institutional joint ventures. We really need to leverage our side of the returns with fees and other things to make the numbers work long term. So, for us it's really not so much about IRRs long term, because it's so dependent on the assumptions. We let at that, that rent [role] that's in place today, what the cash flows are today, and what the risk to those cash flows are over time. -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Samit Parikh, ISI Group - Analyst [82] -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Thanks. -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Operator [83] -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Christy McElroy with UBS. -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Ross Nussbaum, UBS - Analyst [84] -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- It's Ross Nussbaum here with Christy. -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Dave Henry, KIMCO REALTY CORP - Chief Investment Officer [85] -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Oh darn. (laughter) -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Ross Nussbaum, UBS - Analyst [86] -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- You're in trouble now. (laughter) I wanted to push you a little on a comment that was made at the beginning, which was Milton's view that, that cap rates could go to 6% or under. As I look at the implied cap rates on the shopping center REITs today, all the companies are generally trading with one exception. At 6.75% to say 7% cap rates, at least for the, some of the larger companies. And that would suggest to me that it would make sense to start ramping up strategic, larger acquisitions if you truly believe that cap rates are going to go down to a lower level. I'm curious of what you think about that? -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Dave Henry, KIMCO REALTY CORP - Chief Investment Officer [87] -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Well I think it starts with the fact that there is tremendous bidding wars right today for the high-quality stuff that pushes cap rates to 6% or less. We are losing deals all the time to people that are bidding and under 6% going in cap rates. So you don't have to look out, you can just look at what's going on today. And certainly, the trend that Milton is looking at, is cap rates are still going down because demand is exceeding supply and these are good, hard assets that provide a cash flow at a time when people are a little bit worried, width of inflation, a hard asset is good, and so forth. So, for us, as we said before, we start with the quality of the property, the sustainability of that cash flow, whether it is accretive or not to our shareholders and whether we need an institutional partners. -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Ross Nussbaum, UBS - Analyst [88] -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Does it make any sense you that there is nearly 10 publicly traded shopping center REITs with market caps under $1 billion? -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Dave Henry, KIMCO REALTY CORP - Chief Investment Officer [89] -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- No. (laughter) -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Ross Nussbaum, UBS - Analyst [90] -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Are you going to do anything about that? -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Dave Henry, KIMCO REALTY CORP - Chief Investment Officer [91] -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Well, as Milton had always pointed out, M&A is difficult, because by the time you pay for their investment banker, your investment banker, their lawyer, your lawyer, you pay -- and you pay the premium that you need, it starts to get tough to make the numbers work. And then, if you think about most boards of directors, for companies that have made it through this downturn, are not really that prepared to sell at a stock price that is 30%, 40% below where they were a couple of years ago. So, I suspect there'll still be very few M&A deals in our sector. -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Ross Nussbaum, UBS - Analyst [92] -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Thank you. -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Operator [93] -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- This concludes today's question-and-answer session. At this time, Mr. Bujnicki, I will turn the conference back over to you for any additional or closing remarks, sir. -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- David Bujnicki, Kimco Realty Corporation - Sr Dir of IR [94] -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- A final reminder; our supplemental is posted on our website at www.KimcoRealty.com. Thank you for participating today. -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Operator [95] -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- This concludes today's conference. Thank you for your participation.

Event.eventTitle: Q4 2010 Kimco Realty Corporation Earnings Conference Call
